Dear Mr. Nolan:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 8/10-
8/14/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,

II. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
1 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained an annual evaluation that remained
in “pending” status despite being due in April of 2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing
the placement of a child in the home.
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to
accept the foster child
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing
transaction record documents from the certifying agency.
4

3 of 3 foster home files reviewed did not have all of the documentation completed as
required. One file did not have written agency endorsement on home evaluations
and the other two file did not have documents required in all subsections prior to the
youth’s placement in the home.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the
department’s licensing authority within 5 working days in
the manner prescribed by the department.
1 of 8 open foster home files reviewed contained one special evaluation in which the
required special investigation record (259) was not submitted within 5 business
days.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be
reviewed and updated at least once every 90 calendar days
and a copy provided to the youth.
3 of 3 open independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
contract was reviewed and updated every 90 days.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan
(ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
5

Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven business
days of the FTM.
10 of 11 total open youth files reviewed (8 FC + 3 IL) did not have documentation
that FTM requirements were being met. In these cases, FTMs were either missing or
not being completed timely. In addition, there were two cases in which 1105’s were
either not uploaded or were uploaded months after the meeting took place.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/10/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 10/17/2019
FOM 722-08C FOSTER CARE - PARENT-AGENCY TREATMENT PLAN &
SERVICE AGREEMENT
Signatures- When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster
care worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
CI-17-099 All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate
case members within 30 days of the report date.
9 of 11 total open youth files reviewed (8 FC + 3 IL) did not contain all of the PATP
signatures required, including missing caregiver, parent, and youth aged 14+ and
signatures obtained outside of the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as ISEP 6.33
10/10/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 10/17/2019
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
is used to document specific administrative actions or
changes in a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in
6

caseworker or organization. • Change in parent contact
information. • Foster care transfer to adoption. • Change in
placement. • Temporary break from placement. • Program
or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile
justice program/case closure.
4 of 4 closed foster care case files reviewed did not contain program closure action
summaries.
FOM 722-09 FOSTER CARE - UPDATED SERVICE PLAN
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of
the report date.
1 of 11 total open youth files reviewed (8 FC + 3 IL) contained I service plan that
was reviewed 1 day outside of the required timeframe.
FOM 722-16 DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report
The DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, must be
completed with the youth during each home visit. The
original must be placed in the case record and a copy must
be given to the youth.
3 of 3 open young adult files reviewed did not contain any 1295 forms.
FOM 801-3 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
7

All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
3 of 11 total open youth files reviewed (8 FC + 3 IL) did not contain all medical
passports as required. Two cases did not have initial placement medical passports
and on file did not have the form updated quarterly.
ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the foster
care worker and the Department of Health and Services
(DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of service cases for
inclusion in the child’s permanent record. The DHS-222,
Adoption Closing Summary must be used for this purpose.
1 of 5 finalized adoption files reviewed contained a closing summary that was
completed outside of the required timeframe.
SRM 103 In-Service Training
MDHHS and private caseload-carrying staff and specialized
support staff must complete 32 hours of in-service training
each calendar year. First line supervisors who manage
caseload-carrying staff or specialized support staff must
complete 16 hours of in-service training each calendar
year.
1 of 10 personnel files reviewed contained a training record that did not document
that all of the required training hours were completed.
SRM 200 Personnel Training
Security Awareness Training is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access
and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes SAT
timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all employee
personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts to confirm
completion of training
8

5 of 15 applicable employee training records reviewed did not contain
documentation that the SAT training was completed as required. Two of the five
employees are currently with the agency and three are no longer with the agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/27/2020 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 8/28/2020
FOM 722-03C OLDER YOUTH: PREPARATION, PLACEMENT, AND
DISCHARGE
Life Skills Assessment - The Casey Life Skills Assessment
must be completed within 90 days of a youth turning 14,
and annually thereafter. For youth who are 14 or older when
they enter care, the assessment should be completed
within 90 days of entering care.
For youth who are placed in residential, it is the residential
case worker who ensures the Casey Life Skills Assessment
if completed.
Placement in independent living may be an acceptable
living arrangement for youth 16 years or older. Prior to
placement in independent living, the caseworker must
assess the youth, with the Casey Life Skills Assessment, as
being prepared for independent living and demonstrate a
pattern of mature decision making.
3 of 3 independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
Casey Life Skills Assessment was completed as required.
III. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Foster home evaluation reports must include the dates emergency procedures were
practiced by the family, not just the months.
Ensure that all edits intended to be removed from reports are removed prior to
approving the reports.
Be sure that the service plan/PATP signatures are uploaded into the correct case
file.
Ensure that all signatures on documents are also dated at the time the signature on
obtained.
9

IV. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was required.
V. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period. The agency is not incompliance
with the following as noted within the violations in this report:
8/27/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 8/28/20
Chief Administrator Assessment – I reviewed the Chief Administrator Assessment
which indicated that while the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions and staff turnover
made compliance difficult the CAP submitted following the 2020 licensing inspection
has had a positive impact resulting in improved compliance overall. The findings of
this inspection corroborate the assessment, with the addition of concerns related to
specific staff performance issues that were addressed as timely as possible.
CHRI - On 8/9/2021, while on-site, I viewed the storage of the locked storage areas
for CHRI information. I also viewed the dissemination and destruction logs stored in
this secure area as well as the cross shredder.
Other Document Review - On 8/9/2021 I reviewed the agency’s organization chart,
case ratios, and financial audit. I also discussed the AFPRR with administration and
supervisors while on-site.
Staff Interviews – The staff reported that there has been regular communication
and support provided by supervision despite remote work. No concerns were
identified during the interviews.
VI. ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified no safety concerns.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
